cards.frontContent: What does HTML stand for?
What is the purpose of HTML?
cards.backContent: HTML is used to create the structure of a web page by defining elements like headings, paragraphs, links, images, etc.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML element?
cards.backContent: An HTML element is a building block of a web page. It consists of a start tag, content, and an end tag. Example: <tag>content</tag>

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML tag?
cards.backContent: An HTML tag is a special code that is used to define various elements on a web page. Tags are enclosed in angle brackets (<>).

cards.frontContent: What is the basic structure of an HTML document?
cards.backContent:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Title of the page</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    Content of the page
  </body>
</html>

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration?
cards.backContent: It specifies the version of HTML that the document is using. In this case, it indicates HTML5.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML attribute?
cards.backContent: An HTML attribute provides additional information about an element. Attributes are always included in the opening tag and are written as name-value pairs (name="value").

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML class?
cards.backContent: An HTML class is an attribute used to apply styles or behaviors to multiple elements with the same class name. It is defined using the class attribute.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML ID?
cards.backContent: An HTML ID is a unique identifier for an element. It is used to apply styles or behaviors to a specific element. It is defined using the id attribute.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML hyperlink?
cards.backContent: An HTML hyperlink (or anchor) is used to create a clickable link to another page or resource. It is defined using the <a> element.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML list?
cards.backContent: An HTML list is used to organize content into an ordered or unordered list. It is defined using the <ul> (unordered) or <ol> (ordered) element, along with <li> elements for each list item.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML image element?
cards.backContent: The element is used to display an image on a web page. It is a self-closing tag and requires the 'src' attribute to specify the image source.

cards.frontContent: What does CSS stand for?
What is the purpose of CSS?
cards.backContent: CSS is used to style the visual presentation of a web page. It controls layout, colors, fonts, and other design aspects.

cards.frontContent: What is the basic syntax of a CSS rule?
What is a CSS selector?
cards.backContent: A CSS selector is used to target and apply styles to HTML elements. It can be an element name, class, ID, or other attribute.

cards.frontContent: What is the 'box model' in CSS?
cards.backContent: The box model refers to how elements are structured in CSS, including content, padding, border, and margin.

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of 'padding' in CSS?
cards.backContent: Padding is the space between the content of an element and its border. It can be used to create space around an element's content.

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of 'margin' in CSS?
cards.backContent: Margin is the space outside an element. It controls the space between elements on a page.

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of 'border' in CSS?
cards.backContent: Border is the area around an element's content and padding. It can be used to create visual boundaries.

cards.frontContent: What is a CSS class selector?
cards.backContent: A class selector targets elements with a specific class attribute. It is denoted by a period (.) followed by the class name.

cards.frontContent: What is a CSS ID selector?
cards.backContent: An ID selector targets a specific element with a unique ID attribute. It is denoted by a hash (#) followed by the ID name.

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of 'float' in CSS?
cards.backContent: The 'float' property is used to position elements horizontally. It can be used to create a multi-column layout.

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of 'display' property in CSS?
cards.backContent: The 'display' property determines how an element should be displayed on a web page. It can change the behavior of elements from block to inline, or vice versa.

cards.frontContent: What is JavaScript?
cards.backContent: JavaScript is a high-level programming language that is commonly used to create interactive effects within web browsers.

cards.frontContent: Who developed JavaScript?
What is the purpose of a 'for' loop in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: A 'for' loop is used to repeatedly execute a block of code a specified number of times.

cards.frontContent: What is a 'closure' in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: A closure is a function that has access to its own scope, the outer function's scope, and the global scope, even after the outer function has finished executing.

cards.frontContent: What is 'hoisting' in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: Hoisting is a mechanism in JavaScript that moves variable and function declarations to the top of their containing scope during the compile phase.

cards.frontContent: What is an 'arrow function' in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: An arrow function is a more concise way to write function expressions in JavaScript. It does not have its own 'this' and 'arguments' binding.

cards.frontContent: What is 'callback hell' in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: Callback hell refers to the situation where callbacks are nested within other callbacks, leading to code that is hard to read and maintain.

cards.frontContent: What is 'JSON' in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write and easy for machines to parse and generate.

cards.frontContent: What is the purpose of the 'typeof' operator in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: The 'typeof' operator is used to determine the data type of a variable or expression.

cards.frontContent: What is 'ECMAScript'?
cards.backContent: ECMAScript is the standard upon which JavaScript is based. It is maintained by ECMA International.

cards.frontContent: What is a 'promise' in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: A promise is an object that represents the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.

cards.frontContent: What does 'DOM' stand for in the context of JavaScript?
cards.backContent: DOM stands for Document Object Model. It represents the structure of a document as a tree of objects, allowing programs to manipulate the content and structure of a document.

cards.frontContent:
What has roots as nobody sees,
Is taller than trees,
Up, up it goes,
And yet never grows?

Voiceless it cries,
Wingless flutters,
Toothless bites,
Mouthless mutters.

An eye in a blue face
Saw an eye in a green face.
'That eye is like to this eye'
Said the first eye,
'But in low place,
Not in high place.'

It cannot be seen, cannot be felt,
Cannot be heard, cannot be smelt.
It lies behind stars and under hills,
And empty holes it fills.
It comes first and follows after,
Ends life, kills laughter.

A box without hinges, key, or lid,
Yet golden treasure inside is hid.

Alive without breath,
As cold as death;
Never thirsty, ever drinking,
All in mail never clinking.

No-legs lay on one-leg,
two-legs sat near on three-legs,
four-legs got some.
cards.backContent: Fish on a little table, man on a stool, the cat gets the scraps.
